body: @sandeep-krishnamurthy I'm running into the same error.  Installing graphviz in my python environment doesn't fix the issue, and I'm trying to build mxnet with the graphviz dependency but without any luck.  Any advice?
@bearnshaw You need to add graphviz's binary path into your PATH. It seems that mxnet is calling external commands about graphviz.
I like the blue best but "MXNet" text could be better.

@tornadomeet 
Yeah,the .lst file above was generated by im2rec.py , I did make --shuffle=True...Is this a bug?And the label I think should be int not float...
you should shuffle your list file `before` you use im2rec, just see my first commit. you can do shuffle in linux cmd like this ```shuf train.lst -o tran.lst```

if your image label is correct, then you need try batch-size, lr.  what's your input data shape?

data_shape=(3,224,224)
batch_size=10
lr=0.01, lr_factor=1, lr_factor_epoch=1

does your val data only has one label?
thanks @inflation, turns out that `conda install graphviz` only gets the c libraries, and not the python bindings.  Following this up with `pip install graphviz` gets the python bindings.

@tornadomeet 
Thanks for your advice...
When I change batch_size and lr....it seems alright....Thank you very much
Closed.
what happened to R lint?

Correct. Installing will only get the binaries. But, we need pip install to get python bindings and lib path added correctly to PYTHONPATH.

This issue can be closed as I have submitted fix in this PR - https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/4240
@piiswrong I find the python test fails because when I use `a = mx.nd.ones(shape=(10,10), ctx=mx.cpu(1))` , the context of a will still be `mx.cpu(0)`.

@piiswrong  : Please add image copied above to https://github.com/dmlc/web-data/tree/master/mxnet/image/ folder with name - "SampleNetworkVisualization.png"

This image is referenced in the new page added in this commit - http://mxnet.io/how_to/visualize_graph.html
@zhreshold Can u propose a design? I can afford some time to help as well.

I solved this problem by modify the demo.py:
Change line 85 from "ctx = mx.gpu(args.gpu_id)" to "ctx = mx.cpu()"
The system should take care of the process, as well as nvidia-smi. You can try to soft-reset the GPU. But it will also affect other processes.
Filed #4248 and #4249 to support mean and std deviation operators.
I think this is fixed now. Thanks @piiswrong
Please also take care once this feature is merged to nnvm branch.
Amazon Linux is based on RHEL. So the guide maybe also works though.
please fix lint. also please directly submit this to nnvm. We are not accepting PR on master for this part of code
@glingyan if i remember correctly, previous make will automatically run `prepare_mkl.sh` is MKL flag is set. now we need to do it manually?
well, i think we need to specify `MKLML_ROOT` for make. can you please update Makefile, if it is not specified, use `MXNET_ROOT/mklml` as the default location?

confirmed #4085 is fixed. 

but one more problem is resnet is 10x slower on cpu than single k40. can you please double check if there is something not correctly set?
logo is too left, we should vertically align it with text below. also search bar is not horizontally aligned.
For the search box, I changed it to different line to make room for navigation items on small size screen. If we want all stuffs in the same line, I can continue adjusting the layout.
1) change english into Eng, 2) make the box smaller, 3) remove the go button, and change "Search" into "Search, press <Enter> to go"
we can also remove "get started" in the navbar
Sounds good.

@liangfu nice finding. I don't think OpenMP is necessary since BLAS can take all CPUs, glad that mac can remove OpenMP dependency. Would you like to submit a pull request so other Mac users can learn from it? Thanks.

@mli:

1.      Make will execute prepare_mkl.sh as before , By default, USE_BLAS=atlas, MKLML_ROOT=/usr/local

a.      Makefile will use prepare_mkl.sh 0 $MKLML_ROOT to download mkl

2.      I have tested in multi-machine, but have no problem

a.      My college get the same problem as you when run  prepare_mkl.sh directly, so I guest your cause is the same

@nicklhy Well, I never encountered those problems. You can try rmmod + insmod nvidia.ko. But this will also stop everything running on the GPU at that time.

@inflation , already tried your soft-reset method. But I failed to rmmod nvidia(nvidia_uvm).
```
sudo rmmod nvidia_uvm
(rmmod: ERROR: Module nvidia_uvm is in use)
sudo rmmod nvidia_uvm
(rmmod: ERROR: Module nvidia_uvm is in use)
sudo rmmod -f nvidia_uvm
(rmmod: ERROR: ../libkmod/libkmod-module.c:793 kmod_module_remove_module() could not remove 'nvidia_uvm': Resource temporarily unavailable
rmmod: ERROR: could not remove module nvidia_uvm: Resource temporarily unavailable)
```

Mxnet requires gcc 4.8 or later. The default compiler for RHEL 6 is gcc 4.4. You need to upgrade your gcc, or even better upgrade the OS.
http://mxnet.io/get_started/setup.html#minimum-requirements
i'm not familiar with ARM, in may pc cpu, this indeed speed up. but it maybe due to your model, such as  model-size.

@phunterlau It's nice to consider adding native support for macOS. But is there any continuous integration systems (like travis-ci) that support checking the compatibility of future versions? Then I would submit a PR. 
BTW, I don't think BLAS would automaticly take all CPUs, systems like OpenBLAS support changing number of threads only at compile time, not at run-time. So, manually handle multi-threading with features like OpenMP is usually necessary.

What do you mean native support for macOS?

Actually all travis-ci tests we have now are on OSX.

We can have both. The reason I want to move it to jenkins is that R test takes quite a long time.

To meet the time limit on Travis-CI, some examples and test are disabled.
@nicklhy How about a `nvidia-smi -r`?

I have tried that, but since a zombie process is not an alive process. You can not kill it like that.
I also tried to send SIGCHLD to its current parent `sudo kill -s SIGCHLD 1`. But it does not help too.
because when called `get()` for a `metric`, the count is 0, which is often due to `reset()` is called. it  doesn't not affect model, but sometime annoying.
building gcc 4.8 is straightforward: http://mxnet.io/get_started/setup.html#building-gcc-from-source-code

multi-gpus should report (almost) the same accuracy as a simple gpu. one way to check is try https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/score.py , it can load a model and evaluate it using various number of gpus.
try `export MXNET_BACKWARD_DO_MIRROR=1; python xxx` ?
Is there anyone who tried AMD HIP tools on MXNet?

The r lint problem also popped up on my machine. It wasn't failing before. Does anyone know why suddenly we have errors like this:
R-package/src/symbol.h:6:  #ifndef header guard has wrong style, please use: R_PACKAGE_SRC_SYMBOL_H_  [build/header_guard] [5]

I found the issue. Was due to this change in dmlc-core: https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/commit/a3b2fbeb360a15cfbfd5762dd62c1b81309f5c6a#diff-460cb56a7855c776ca8943d6f4f2c6c4
Will pr to dmlc-core to fix it. Please update dmlc-core afterwards
@mli many thanks，it's really annoying...
This pull request is *not* ready for merge
i think this is a multi-class regression example? in multi-label regression, there is no softmax constrain across label dimensions.

I had an environment variable called BIN that seemed to be interfering with building mxnet causing errors of the form

```
cd /Users/rohit/src/mxnet/dmlc-core; make libdmlc.a USE_SSE=1 config=/Users/rohit/src/mxnet/config.mk; cd /Users/rohit/src/mxnet
make[1]: `libdmlc.a' is up to date.
clang++ -DMSHADOW_FORCE_STREAM -Wall -O3 -I/Users/rohit/src/mxnet/mshadow/ -I/Users/rohit/src/mxnet/dmlc-core/include -fPIC -Iinclude -funroll-loops -Wno-unused-parameter -Wno-unknown-pragmas -Wno-unused-local-typedefs -msse3 -DMSHADOW_USE_CUDA=0 -DMSHADOW_USE_CBLAS=1 -DMSHADOW_USE_MKL=0 -DMSHADOW_RABIT_PS=0 -DMSHADOW_DIST_PS=0 -DMSDHADOW_USE_PASCAL=0 -DMXNET_USE_OPENCV=1 -I/usr/local/Cellar/opencv/2.4.13.1/include/opencv -I/usr/local/Cellar/opencv/2.4.13.1/include -I/usr/local/opt/openblas/include -DMXNET_USE_NVRTC=0 -std=c++11  -o /Users/rohit/src/mxnet/beam/bazel/bin/Users/rohit/src/mxnet  -pthread -lm -lopenblas  -L/usr/local/Cellar/opencv/2.4.13.1/lib -lopencv_calib3d -lopencv_contrib -lopencv_core -lopencv_features2d -lopencv_flann -lopencv_gpu -lopencv_highgui -lopencv_imgproc -lopencv_legacy -lopencv_ml -lopencv_nonfree -lopencv_objdetect -lopencv_ocl -lopencv_photo -lopencv_stitching -lopencv_superres -lopencv_ts -lopencv_video -lopencv_videostab -L/usr/local/opt/openblas/lib -L/usr/local/lib/graphviz/
clang: warning: argument unused during compilation: '-pthread'
Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:
  "_main", referenced from:
     implicit entry/start for main executable
ld: symbol(s) not found for architecture x86_64
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
make: *** [/Users/rohit/src/mxnet/beam/bazel/bin/Users/rohit/src/mxnet] Error 1
```

Unsetting `BIN` and building seemed to fix this:
```
mxnet$ BIN= make -j8
```

Additionally, I also did the following to build mxnet on MacOS Sierra (10.12.1) though I'm not sure how much of this is really necessary:

```
$ HOMEBREW_CC=clang brew install openblas
```
Add/modify the following lines in config.mk:
```
export CC=clang
export CXX=clang++

ADD_LDFLAGS = -L/usr/local/opt/openblas/lib -L/usr/local/lib/graphviz/
ADD_CFLAGS = -I/usr/local/opt/openblas/include

USE_BLAS = openblas
```

DISCLAIMER: I just started mucking around with mxnet a few hours back and have only tried the python example after doing this. Your machine (and my machine after a few hours) may still choose to blow up :)
You can submit a PR. We appreciate your help.

I submitted a PR intend to add support for Mac. see PR #4260 
@rohitsaboo My personal solution to add OpenBLAS is to download the code from github, compile and install from the source code. After installation, the library would be installed into `/usr/local`, specifically at /usr/local/include and /usr/local/lib. Then after configuring the library with cmake targeting XCode to compile, everything goes fine without any unexpected error.

> For Keras, we need support for Sparse Matrices

If you leave out sparse tensor support, very little functionality would be lost. As long as you raise appropriate, helpful exceptions in the backend, it would be fine.

Do you foresee any issues with `K.rnn`, `K.gradients`? These two would be the tricky ones.

@piiswrong I see that MXSymbolGrad is not yet implemented in NNVM branch. Is it in the works?

I think mx.image.ImageIter could be a very good starting point to unify the interface of DataIter for object detection problem.
The differences/difficulties are:

1. Label width varies from image to image because # object varies, this have to be solved by padding or special process before loading the labels. Thus rec files must be prepared accordingly, I think it's better to unify this behavior across tasks.

2. Data augmentations such like lighting/colorjitter/colornomalize can be reused from current functions, however, anything related to spatial transform must be handled differently: augmenter must take in label as well, cropping/flipping image will result in different labels.

3. as a result of 2, the format of label for object detection tasks should be fixed, so we can always reuse the augmenter functions. Essentially we need labels in formats like this for each image:
(im_width, im_height) - required for those using non-fixed size inputs(fast(er)-rcnn, etc) 
(object_id, xmin, ymin, xmax, ymax) x N - proportional or absolute bounding boxes

Just wondering if you guys ever had plans or ideas like this? @piiswrong @sxjscience @precedenceguo
@jspisak Could you put the log into docs

1. you can pack array as label into rec and each record can have different label length
2. the crop func etc returns the transformed image along with coordinates. So you can write a wrapper that transform the label
gradient is in there (gradient pass) but not exposed through c api. @tqchen @jermainewang  Is it possible to expose it?
@piiswrong -  Fixed indentation issue.

@mli @ptrendx changed auto tuning strategy to be on by default. 

@mli We need to remove the cudnn_tune: 0 field from all pretrained symbols so they can benefit from this (they won't break if we don't but tuning would still be off if you load those symbols)
@dytan this works for me on **ubuntu 16.04**, can't figure out the reason.
Hi @zhangjiulong, I meet the similar problem when using warp-ctc and bucketing, I doubt whether warp-ctc support bucketing. Do you have any idea?

@xlvector Does warp-ctc plugin support bucketing? I implemented cnn-bi_lstm-ctc with buckets in order to fit variable input image length, but I find it all the outputs of final layer remain same during training, however it will converge if I resized all images to fixed length and only use one bucket.
So I guess warp-ctc may not be compatible with bucketing.

@Ldpe2G , sure, I can make a PR about this.

First, if you agree, I will just change the default value IndexedSeq.empty because this way, it doesn't change / break the API of NDArrayIter.

In the long term, I think it would be better the use an Option[IndexedSeq] with a default of None; it is the idiomatic Scala way to express optional values. This would change the NDArrayIter API.

I should be able to do this in the next few days (but not before Monday).

Regarding this discussion (re: Yarin Gal's RNN implementation): 

> @sxjscience: you should be explicit by what dropout you are referring to. Is it the version from "
> A Theoretically Grounded Application of Dropout in Recurrent Neural Networks" (https://arxiv.org/pdf/1512.05287.pdf), or from the older and less good (arXiv:1409.2329v5)? (or support both as options)

> @sbodenstein Currently we've just coded the old version. The dropout method in the NIPS paper should be added later. Also, the performance boost in the paper is partially due to the dropout method for the embedding layer and we can also support it.

According to Yarin, his implementation is already in  Keras, TensorFlow, and Torch. I think it basically uses the same dropout mask across timesteps on RNNs. The implementations might include examples to handle RNN layers of different sizes, and I also speculate the potential of allowing for uncertainty in RNN predictions as that research continues.

See:
https://github.com/yaringal/BayesianRNN/issues/3

I find that the "dropout" used in the paper is actually a type of "DropConnect"(http://www.jmlr.org/proceedings/papers/v28/wan13.pdf) that directly masks the weight matrix. I'm thinking to keep its original name.
